newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Japanese fish market lures Australia.
newsitem.headline: Japanese fish market lures Australia.

text.p: A major Australian government report into the huge Japanese import market highlights the US$8.28 billion market for imported fish, shrimp and prawn as an area where Australia could tap big demand.
Australia's food exports to Japan are presently dominated by the exports of beef (worth US$1.24 billion in 1995), raw sugar (US$253.8 million) and wheat (US$250.8 million).

But Japan's total imports of shrimp and prawns, worth US$3.94 billion in 1995, of bonito and tuna, worth US$2.01 billion, and of processed fish, worth $2.34 billion in the same year, are together worth almost three times the country's imported beef market of US$3.26 billion, the report shows.
The report, A New Japan? Change in Asia's Megamarket, emphasises Australia's low market share in processed fish.
In 1995, Australia exported only US$34.1 million worth of processed fish, US$134.1 million worth of shrimps and prawns and US$64.5 million worth of tuna to Japan.
Fish and prawns are just two big Japanese markets --- although very notable examples --- which Australian agricultural commodities could tap, the report says.

In 1995 Australia supplied only US$4.6 million worth of exports to a US$1.24 billion Japanese imported vegetable, roots and tubers market. It exported only US$13.4 million of preserved fruits and foods to a total Japanese import market of US$854.2 million. And it exported only US$1.2 million to a US$315.9 million non-alcoholic beverages (mainly mineral water) market.

"Australia could improve substantially its exports of fish, vegetables, roots and tubers, preserved fruit and foods and non-alcoholic beverages," said the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's (DFAT) East Asia Analytical Unit.

Japanese processed foods markets where Australian exports are performing well are fruit and vegetable juices (US$46.7 million Australian exports in total Japanese imports of US$538.9 million), chocolate and other foods containing cocoa (US$37.5 million in total imports of US$319.3 million), malt (US$54.3 million in imports of US$300.0 million) and alcoholic beverages (US$16.8 million in imports of US$1.96 billion).

The DFAT report closely follows a report by the Australian government's official commodity forecasting group, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE), into Australian aquaculture.
This report said aquaculture was a rapidly-growing Australian industry, now accounting for 25 percent of Australia's fisheries production.

But Australia remained a relatively small producer in world prawn aquaculture, with Thailand the world's largest producer. Thailand has a market share of 27 percent of world farmed prawn production, followed by Indonesia on 19 percent, the Philippines 12 percent, China 11 percent, and Ecuador 11 percent.
Of the two prawn species farmed in Australia, black tiger and kuruma prawns, Australia contributed less than one percent of total world supplies of 443,128 tonnes, it said.
In 1995, Japan imported 172 tonnes of Australian prawns in total imports of 474 tonnes of live prawns, with China the leading supplier, the study showed.

Total Australian agrifood exports to Japan in 1995 amounted to US$3.23 billion, with Australia ranking as Japan's largest foreign supplier of sugar, dairy foods and rice, its second-largest supplier of beef, cattle and canola and its third largest supplier of meat, wheat and other food products.
DFAT officials who prepared the Japan report said they were not aware of structural or other difficulties which would bar Australia supplying Japan's big fish and prawn markets.
